original_title: Senate Passes Infrastructure Bill with Bipartisan Support
original_body:
The U.S. Senate passed a $1.2 trillion infrastructure bill on Thursday with a vote of 69-30, sending the legislation to the House of Representatives for consideration.

The bill includes $550 billion in new federal spending over five years, targeting roads, bridges, public transit, broadband internet, and water systems. Nineteen Republican senators joined all 50 Democrats in supporting the measure.

Senator Rob Portman of Ohio, a lead Republican negotiator, called the bill "a historic investment in American infrastructure." Democratic Senator Kyrsten Sinema of Arizona, another key negotiator, said the legislation "will create jobs and strengthen our economy."

The bill allocates $110 billion for roads and bridges, $66 billion for passenger and freight rail, $65 billion for broadband expansion, and $55 billion for clean water infrastructure.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has indicated she will not bring the bill to a vote until the Senate also passes a larger budget reconciliation package. The timeline for House consideration remains uncertain.
